title: Illustrations of damnation in late Anglo-Saxon manuscripts.
abstract: This paper interprets a group of innovative illustrations from the eleventh century English manuscript, the Harley Psalter, in the context of textual, documentary, place-name and archaeological evidence for an uniquely late Anglo-Saxon conception of barrows, ancient monuments and deviant burial places as places of damnation and hellish torment

        Illustrations of damnation in late Anglo-Saxon manuscripts.</dc:title><dc:creator>
        Semple,  S. J.</dc:creator><dc:description>
        This paper interprets a group of innovative illustrations from the eleventh century English manuscript, the Harley Psalter, in the context of textual, documentary, place-name and archaeological evidence for an uniquely late Anglo-Saxon conception of barrows, ancient monuments and deviant burial places as places of damnation and hellish torment.</dc:description><dc:subject>
